title: Knight Digital Media Center GeoRSS Fellows Stories feed
name: Knight Digital Media Center GeoRSS Fellows Stories feed
description: Locations of new media stories published by alumni of KDMC training programs.

properties.title: Addict Fed Up, Pleads Up to Receive Drug Treatment
properties.description: Damon Conrow, a young Heroin addict,  made the drastic decision to plead to a higher criminal charge in order to enter the Central Utah Correctional Facility's substance abuse treatment program.  Djmila used a variety of techniques to amplify for viewers Conrow's revulsion and despair at his conditi

properties.title: The Grand Hotel Spruces Up for another Season
properties.description:
The majestic Grand Hotel has received guests since 1887. Located on Mackinac island off the northern tip of Michigan, the hotel is a popular summer retreat for vacationers.  The hotel is open only six months out of the year, so a lot of work goes into getting it ready.

Eric Seales (May 08), a multimedia journalist for the Detroit Free Press, spent two days shooting to create a video profile on the hotel and the family that has run it for three generations.

properties.title: One Man's Trash is this Man's Treasure. Sometimes.
properties.description: Scott Smith (Jun '08) of the Stockton Record used a slide show to tell the tale of a treasure hunter who became the bewildered owner of over 6,000 dental records.

properties.title: Sidney Barnes on Stone Cold Feeling
properties.description: A favorite record of mine, a B-Side from 1971, was written in Chicago, featured a Chicago artist and players, was recorded in Chicago, and was released on a Chicago label (Mercury). I had the opportunity to talk to the man who wrote it, Sidney Barnes, about it; and I flashed-back vicariously through him (he hadn't heard the track in thirty years).

properties.title: Meera's articles
properties.description: Links to Meera's articles can be found here.

properties.title: New Site Combines Social Networking and Digital Media
properties.description: News Entrepreneurs Boot Camp fellow Ingrid Sturgis helped produce fully-connected.com, which "connects people from Atlanta to Accra through engaging journalism and social networking."

properties.title: OC Register Immigrant Labor Series
properties.description: April 2008 fellow Ron Campbell has posted Part 2 of OC Register's series on immigrants and the California economy. This part examines the breakdown of immigration law enforcement. Also see <a href="http://www.ocregister.com/articles/-265578--.html">interactive maps </a>(click the 'maps' tab).

properties.title: Video Promotes UC's PRIME Medical Program
properties.description: July 2008 fellow Alec Rosenberg shares this video about UC's PRIME (Program in Medical Education). PRIME trains doctors to serve where they are needed most in California.

properties.title: Video revisists 40-year-old case of slain journalist
properties.description: January 2008 fellow Robert Lopez produced this video on deadline last week about former L.A. Times columnist Ruben Salazar's death. Questions and controversy still cloud the 40-year-old case.

properties.title: Brown Pelican Release
properties.description: Vanessa Deggins reports on The Louisiana Dept of Wildlife and Fisheries and their first in-state release of Brown Pelicans impacted by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

properties.title: First Lake Charles Black Rodeo
properties.description: Vanessa Deggins reports on Lake Charles's first Real Cowboy Association Rodeo. The association was started years ago in Longview, TX for black cowboys, but has since integrated and everyone competes.

properties.title: The Art of the Foul Ball
properties.description: May 2008 fellow Eric Seals records the stories of those lucky enough to grab a major league baseball souvenir. More multimedia coverage of that same day at the ballpark can be found <a href="http://www.google.com/url?sa=D&amp;q=http://www.freep.com/article/20100801/SPORTS02/100731011%26template%3Daltart&amp;usg=AFQjCNHGlKIJ6A3hX6ECDGdpYVWwE8A_QA">here</a>.

properties.title: Animal Hoarding in Fort Wayne
properties.description: May 2009 fellow Ron Shawgo shares this video on the increasingly serious problem of animal hoarding.

properties.title: UC Davis project puts conventional and organic gardening in a one-hundred-year bout.
properties.description: Stephanie Ogburn (Jan '10) produced some videos for the <a href="http://asi.ucdavis.edu/">Agricultural Sustainability Institute (ASI) at UC Davis </a>.  The first is about an experiment to see whether tomatoes grow better with <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_qvSAWnQ-9I"> conventional or organic growing techniques</a>.  In the other a Stanford professor talks about the <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gI3r-bSjsH8"> pros and cons of agricultural nitrogen fertilizer</a>.

properties.title: Crime on Cruise Ships
properties.description: Jaclyn Giovis presents video and data to help cruise passengers avoid crime.

properties.title: Five Years Later: Hurricane Katrina
properties.description: January 20008 fellow Julia Schmalz contributed work to producing a multimedia site which recalls the devastation associated with Hurricane Katrina.

properties.title: Whitening The Resume
properties.description: With blacks being re-employed during the recovery at a slower pace than whites, should black candidates consider removing ethnic references from their resumes?

properties.title: California's addiction to immigrant labor
properties.description:
California is addicted to immigrant labor.
Over the past four decades, the state has come to depend on immigrant brains and brawn to an extent unmatched by any other state and almost any developed country.

properties.title: Who wins or loses from mass immigration?
properties.description: Part 3 of OC Register immigration series examines impact of immigration on wages. Scroll down left side of story to link to <strong>interactive charts</strong> showing shift in wages by education and occupation from 1970 to 2008.

properties.title: Detroit crime victims, victimized again
properties.description:
Eighty-nine year old Irene Phimister was beaten to an inch of her life over six dollars and a handful of jewelry so a few guys could feed their heroin habit. Irene is owed $1,200 but has yet to see it. Hundreds of crime victims like her in Metro Detroit are still waiting on millions in restitution money to be mailed to them. The process to pay has been a long, slow and often times non-existent. The prosecutors and clerks office blame each other while the money just sits in a bank and victims sit and wait.
ERIC SEALS/Detroit ...

properties.title: Columbia Stink Map
properties.description: Crowd sourcing of where people in Columbia, South Carolina smelled something foul on Tuesday, Oct. 26. Reporters tracked down the source of the odor to a farm south of the city, where the owner (a former city councilman) had spread fertilizer.

properties.title: The Grapevine Brings Deaf Taxman More Business
properties.description:
Gary Jacobson is a 60-year-old accountant who helps deaf and hard of hearing clients with their taxes. Patricia Nazario (Dec '09) got the story in text, radio and video.

Nazario is a broadcast journalist for KPCC 89.3 FM in Los Angeles.

properties.title: Hawaii Ukulele Festival
properties.description: Heidi Chang produced a radio story, video and slideshow capturing why thousands of people from around the globe turned out to attend the 40th annual Ukulele Festival in Hawaii (July 2010). The instrument has seen a resurgence lately, thanks in part to musician Jake Shimabukuro. You can watch his performance at the festival on video.

properties.title: Video: Take the Walking School Bus on Wednesday For Health, Environment
properties.description: Video follows the "Walking School Bus" one morning as the bus picks up kids along its route and makes its way to Marin School in Albany. Interviews with the organizer, some kids and the school principal along the way.

properties.title: AHS Jazz Band Sent to Lincoln Center
properties.description: This video brings viewers into a practice session of this award-winning jazz band on the eve of a trip to Lincoln Center. The video zooms in for close ups on two of the most stellar performers as they regal listeners with solos.

properties.title: Democrats and Republicans Hit Voter Rallies
properties.description: Democrats and Republicans hit voter rallies in Nueces County. We were there to talk to locals about what happened and to get photos of their appearance.

properties.title: Louisiana National Guard's 256th Infantry Prepares for Iraq
properties.description:
Vanessa Deggins (Jan '09) and collegue Elona Weston documented the 256th infantry while they prepared for a year long tour of duty in Iraq. The soldiers performed exercises at Camp Shelby in Mississippi. Deggins shot and edited a <a href="http://www.vimeo.com/9685447">video of the convoy security training exercise</a>.

Deggins is a multimedia reporter for American Press in Lake Charles, Louisiana.

properties.title: Where the lottery takes the biggest bite
properties.description: Flash map showing analysis of lottery ticket sales and Bright Futures scholarship awards by ZIP code in Hillsborough County, Fla.

properties.title: Reworking the US-Mexico Water Treaty
properties.description:
The Colorado River has been nearly tapped dry as a consequence of exploding populations in the southwest border region combined with the voracious appetite of American agribusiness. 

Mexico and the U-S are now negotiating a decades-old water sharing treaty. If successful, the revamped treaty could provide a model for conserving a vital but finite resource.

properties.title: Mexico: Human Rights & Press Freedom
properties.description:
This is a profile of one courageous journalist's battle to expose police corruption, manipulation of both the media and the lives of those who speak out against abuses of power by government and an explanation of how this landmark case came to the world's attention. 

The fact the journalist is a woman in a machista society complicates an already horrendous breach of human rights, one which is being examined by lawyers internationally.

properties.title: US visa laws lightened for Cuban artists
properties.description:
On his first visit to Latin America President Obama said he'd like to start a path of normalizing relations with Cuba. While visiting Mexico City, Mr. Obama also implied that the frozen relationship would not thaw unless Cuba relaxed pressure on political dissidents.

At the same time, Mr. Obama has allowed more Cuban artists--even those openly critical of U-S policy--to come to the United States.

This story is pegged to the visits of three well-known artists and musicians, all of whom have differing opinions on the delicate dance Washington & Havana are engaged in.

properties.title: It's a Wrap: The "Grill 'Em All" Food Truck Makeover
properties.description:
At the Wrap One shop in Anaheim, a small team transforms blank-slate "taco trucks" into billboards on wheels.

Watch the metamorphosis of the "Grill 'Em All" truck.

***

A Concepts Completos production in association with the documentary: Masa Revolution

***

(Freelance photography and editing by Corey Takahashi / Music courtesy of Shadows Fall)

properties.title: How the West Balanced Its Budgets?
properties.description: Stephanie Ogburn's (Jan '10) new Flash map illustrates how deep the defecits are in many West Coast states. Fortunately, it's not all bad news, Oregon and Montana are in the black.

properties.title: After the Chino Prison Riot
properties.description: Public Insight Journalism crowdsourcing and traditional reporting methods combine to tell the story of the Chino prison riot of August 2009. The web presentation includes dozens of letters written by inmates of a California prison describing conditions before, during and after the riot. Some of the men were held outdoors in metal cages with inadequate clothing and shelter for days after the riot. The story came to KPCC via sources responding to general questions to the public about <a href="www.scpr.org/network/questions/prison">prison life</a>. One of our sources won the SPJ Sunshine Award for efforts to make government more open.

properties.title: KDMC Alum Wins an Award for Showing Business People at Play
properties.description: The Virginia Press Association gave Jennifer Nycz-Conner (May '09) an award for three slideshows she made soon after completing the boot camp. See <a href="http://kdmc.us/au8tyV">Washington chef Jose Andres celebrate the big 4-0</a> at his restaurant Jaleo.  Bobbie Kilberg invited <a href="http://kdmc.us/9rTneX">486 colleagues to a pool party at her house</a> for the Northern Virginia Technology Council's annual Hot Ticket Awards. Area architectural firms competed in the<a href="http://kdmc.us/9zpZSm"> Posh Pumpkin Contest </a>, an event hosted by Office Environments International and All Steel. Nycz-Conner is a reporter for the Washington Business Journal.

properties.title: Invasive Pests
properties.description: Alec Rosenberg (July '08) assembled a package about how the University of California helps to inform the public about invasive pests.

properties.title: Undergraduate Research
properties.description: Harry Mok (Jan '10) helped put together a multimedia package on undergraduate research.  The site has been selected as an upcoming "Webpick of the Day" by Communications Arts.

properties.title: Take a Trip to Minnesota Via Multimedia
properties.description:
Gustave Axelson (Jan '10) assembled a slide show for the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer about a farmer that sued to save his wetlands and won.  

Axelson coached his associate editor on putting together this <a href="http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/volunteer/marapr10/getaways_video.html"> white water rafting</a> trip down the Rice Creek Water Trail.

properties.title: 25th Anniversary of the MOVE confrontation in Philadelphia
properties.description: Larry Kesterson (July '09) and colleagues at the Philadelphia Inquirer produced an extensive feature on the 1985 stand-off between police and the radical group MOVE.  The altercation ended when the city bombed MOVE's bunker on a row home from a helicopter that resulted in burning an entire neighborh

properties.title: Governing California - Making Sense of Our State of Disarray
properties.description: Tyche Hendricks (Jan '10) is the editor for KQED Public Radio's The California Report.  This project is designed to demistify the chaos that is governance in California.

properties.title: Poynter Institute Showcases KDMC Fellows Using Timelines with Dippity
properties.description:
Two KDMC fellows were quoted in a Poynter article about creating interactive timelines using <a href="http://www.dipity.com/">Dipity</a>.

Craig Gima (Jan'10), assistant city editor and reporter at the Honolulu Star-Bulletin, <a href="http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20100211_higa_timeline.html"> produced a timeline to explain an ongoing crime story</a>.  Wendy Norris (Jan '10), editor and publisher at Western Citizen, used a timeline to organize the events of the <a href="http://www.dipity.com/timeline/The-Compleat-Ted-Haggard-Sex-Drugs-And-Hush-Money-Timeline"> Ted Haggard sex and drug scandal</a>.

properties.title: Sandwiches Made with Love. YEAH BABY!
properties.description: Ernie Hassan has made 1 1/2 pound made-to-order sandwiches at his market in Metro Detroit for the past 50 years. Many come for the sandwiches you have to unhinge your jaws to eat, but most return because Hassan treats his customers like family. Eric Seals (May '08) produced the video of Ernie's Market for the Detroit Free Press.

properties.title: Where is Huguette Clark?
properties.description:
Huguette Clark is the daughter of William Andrews Clark, a copper baron who was almost as rich as Rockerfeller. The 103-year-old heiress owns many estates, but doesn't live in any of them.  Bill Dedman (Jan '08) explores the mystery of the ever elusive Huguette in a slideshow for MSNBC.com.

Also see the <a href="http://www.poynter.org/column.asp?id=31&amp;aid=179216">interview with Bill Dedman</a> in E-Media Tidbits about the project.

properties.title: Cow Power Raising a Stink in Central California
properties.description: Some Central Valley dairy farmers use dairy digesters to turn cow manure to electricity.  Unfortunately, this process has come under fire for creating pollution through large concentrations of methane gas.  P.J. Huffstutter (Jan '10) documented the dairy digester process in a slide show for the Los Angeles Times.

properties.title: Art as Public Work
properties.description: Fresh from the January '10 workshop, Glenn Burkins produced his first multimedia package about an art competition for public works employees in Charlotte and Mecklenburg City, North Carolina.

properties.title: Dancing Machine
properties.description: Josh Levoir spends 9 hours, ten dollars of quarters and 9,000 calories during a day of dancing at a video arcade.  Eric Seals (May '08) shot a video that shows how Levoir likes to get in the groove.

properties.title: 48 Hours at the Times Union Center
properties.description: Christen Gowan (July '09) produced a whimiscal video piece that reveals the many faces, and floors, of Albany, New York's Times Union Center.  See how the center can host basketball, hockey and bull riding in one weekend.

properties.title: A Look at the new iPad
properties.description: Ryan Kim (Jan '10) shared his first impressions of Apple's iPad notebook computer with a narrated video tour of the device.

properties.title: Hong Kong Nightlife
properties.description: The Wall Street Journal's Jessica Yu (July 2009) captures the flavor of Hong Kong's exciting nightlife in video and photo.

properties.title: Deaf, but not silent: Priest abuse victim speaks out
properties.description: Sarah Hoye (Jan '09) produced a multimedia package for CNN about Arthur Budzinski, who was molested by a priest while he was a Catholic school student. Budzinski has spoken out for 37 years and plans to keep fighting.

properties.title: Out of Retirement to Save Business
properties.description: Larry Kesterson (July '09) uses video to follow the story of a charismatic 80 year old CEO who has returned from retirement to bring his family chain of department stores back from bankruptcy. Kesterson is a photographer for the Philadelphia Inquirer.

properties.title: Turkey Farm in Metro Detroit
properties.description: KDMC workshop fellow Eric Seals created an excellent video essay about a Turkey Farm in Metro Detroit.

properties.title: High Schoolers Explore Race In Response to the Obama Presidency
properties.description: Sarah Hoye (Jan 09) followed a diverse group of students from the election to the end of the 2009 school year, and produced a thought provoking multimedia piece regarding <a href="http://www2.tbo.com/content/2009/sep/24/students-see-their-world-changing-still-feel-sting/">race in the age of Obama </a>.  Hoye is a multimedia journalist for the Tampa Tribune.

properties.title: KDMC Fellows Win a National Emmy
properties.description: Kathleen Galligan (June 08) and Regina Boone (Jan 08) were part of the Detroit Free Press team that won an Emmy for their multimedia package on Christ Child House, a foster home for boys in Detroit.

properties.title: Assignment Detroit to Chronicle the Fall and Rise of an All-American City
properties.description:
Time Magazine has pledged to follow Detroit closely for the next year.  The findings will be reported in The Detroit Blog. Steven Gray (June 2009) will blog and cover stories for the initiative.  He introduces the project in his post <a href="http://detroit.blogs.time.com/2009/09/20/letter-from-detroit/#more-28">Letter to Detroit</a>.

The New York Times covered the project in <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/21/business/media/21carr.html">Investment in a City of Struggles.</a>

properties.title: May '09 Alum Covers Iran Elections
properties.description: Anna Johnson, an AP reporter and editor based in the Middle East, produced a photo slideshow and a <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3sYzX8uPNk0&amp;feature=channel_page">video</a> on the Iranian elections. Anna was in the KDMC's May 2009 multimedia workshop.

properties.title: P.I. Reed School of Journalism
properties.description: Fellow John Temple, who is associate dean of P.I. Reed School of Journalism implemented a program whereby students of the school will produce multimedia projects for local papers, and in turn teach the staffers at those newspapers on how they did it. Congratulations John on spearheading <a href="http://wvuncovered.wvu.edu/">this program</a>.

properties.title: Hurricane Shelter Mashup
properties.description: Fellow Scott Anderson, video and technology editor for The Times in Shreveport, Louisiana shares with us a Google Map he produced offering locations of hurricane shelters to the public and which ones were over-capacity during Hurricane Gustav.

properties.title: Local Coach's in Video
properties.description: Fellow Eric Seals, photographer and multimedia producer for the Detroit Free Press produced this fantastic video on local coach Courtney Hawkins of Flint (MI) Beecher High School.

properties.title: Jan '09 Alum Produces Multimedia Inauguration Map
properties.description: Heather Charles, Knight multimedia workshop alumna and photojournalist for the The Indianapolis Star, shared a map mashup documenting her trip from President Obama's home town to the inauguration in Washington D.C.

properties.title: Family Struggles with Loss
properties.description: Penelope Carrington, Knight multimedia workshop alumna and a multimedia reporter for the The Richmond Times-Dispatch shares a video on how one family struggles with loss.

properties.title: Interactive Narratives Launched
properties.description: A collection of some of the industry's best work can now be viewed at a site that recently re-launched. Interactive Narratives, sposored by the Online News Association, was set up to preset groundbreaking multimedia stories and interviews with some of the journalists pushing and playing with new forms and new media. The site will feature interviews and allow viewers to rate and comment on the work.

properties.title: A Soldier's Story - The Vietnam Experience Opens at Petaluma Museum
properties.description: Simple slideshow use of digital photos bring a story to life for the reader and are quick and easy to utilize as shown here in an article announcing the opening of a Vietnam War exhibit at a community library

properties.title: Los Angelena on a Metro transit tour
properties.description:
Southern California native Jacki Ueng embarks on her first tour of L.A.'s mass transit system. As the city expands its train routes, it's a trip more car-loving Angelenos are starting to take. Follow Jacki's journey on the Metro Red Line, from Hollywood and Highland to Olvera Street and Thai Town.

(Story, photography and production by Corey Takahashi)

properties.title: Vietnam's economy lures back some who left in the 1970s
properties.description: When the Vietnam War ended 35 years ago, millions of Vietnamese fled a communist country whose growth had been stymied by war, oppression and uncertainty, seeking a better life for themselves and their children in the USA, Canada and Europe. Today, some of those who left years ago now look at Vietnam as a land of opportunity. At least 500,000 Viet Kieu return every year to this nation of 86 million, some to stay. As a growing number invest in Vietnam, it's creating jobs and fueling the country's economy. But the investment may also be seen as ...

properties.title: Ford Hopes Free Driver's Ed in Vietnam Leads to Sales
properties.description: In Vietnam, Ford and other carmakers are using a unique campaign to hook consumers with their cars: Driving schools. Ford's driving school in Ho Chi Minh City aims to teach a nation of bikers and walkers to drive a car.

properties.title: Dreams of Steady Work Fade for Hispanic Workers
properties.description: Since Hurricance Katrina, tens of thousands of Hispanic workers, most of them undocumented, have poured into battered sections of the Gulf Coast. They've supplied the labor to rebuild, to keep businesses running and to boost tax revenue. To support their families back home, they often will work longer hours and for less pay than other laborers. Yet the economic dream that drew them here has weakened. For some, pay is falling. And jobs are scarcer, because the most urgent work — gutting homes and removing debris — is mostly finished. Though years of rebuilding remain, not enough state and insurance money ...

properties.title: Mobile taquerias bring new flavors to New Orleans
properties.description: The smell of sizzling beef and warm flour tortillas beckons from a food truck perched at an intersection here. Food trucks such as this one — offering flavorful, cheap and authentic Latin-American fare — were all but non-existent before Katrina. They now dot the landscape in New Orleans and neighboring Jefferson Parish. Their regular customers are the Hispanic laborers who have migrated here to rebuild homes, but they've also built a following among local residents. Not everyone's a fan. In June, the Jefferson Parish Council voted unanimously to bar mobile vendors from setting up shop at some of the busiest ...

properties.title: Couples and Cash
properties.description: Meet our Money Makeover couples: These couples opened up their financial lives to USA TODAY and the Financial Planning Association. They were matched with financial planners to define their goals and map a path to reach them. Each Monday, we'll profile a couple, and each Friday, we'll offer tips on handling your own finances.

properties.title: Life on Main: Stories from Main Street in Belleville, Ill.
properties.description: Like National Geographic's ZIP code profiles, or the New York Times' One in 8 Million, we decided to use a piece of geography as a starting point to tell photo stories. Main Street is the iconic view of Middle America, and Belleville's got one of the longest at 9.2 miles. We use Soundslides to produce these pieces, which grow in value as we add episodes and people can browse through profiles that catch their attention.

properties.title: Cloquet River Water Trail Interactive Map
properties.description: This Flash interactive map embedded with video clips accompanied a print magazine story about a canoe trip down the Cloquet River.

properties.title: Video poem; The 1st Day of Kindergarten,
properties.description:
Milestones for many parents? Their baby's 1st steps & learning to talk but nothing makes them as nervous & emotional as watching their kids head off to kindergarten. A really nice poem written by a kindergarten teacher called "The First Day" puts it all in perspective.
ERIC SEALS/Detroit Free Press

properties.title: Professional arm wrestling
properties.description:
The Hit Squad is a group of 11 men from Metro Detroit who train & compete for national championships in arm wrestling. Having muscle is a huge help but so is technique, attitude, focus & desire.
ERIC SEALS/Detroit Free Press

properties.title: Remote control car racing takes off!
properties.description:
On any given Saturday during the summer, some grown men go out for a round of golf, some just like to race remote control cars. 
At a dirt track in Metro Detroit these guys race the kind of cars you can't find at Radio Shack or Toys R Us for $50. They are basically scaled down versions of race cars that can go as fast as 60 mph & cost up to $2,000. They all do it not just to feel young again but for the fun, competition and the camaraderie of it all.
ERIC SEALS/Detroit Free Press

properties.title: TV, film producers hang ten in Hawaii
properties.description: This radio story explores why Hawaii, long known as a tourist destination, is becoming a hub for TV and film production. It also takes you to the premiere of “Hawaii Five-0” on Waikiki Beach. The show that put Hawaii on the map in the 60s and 70s is back, entertaining audiences worldwide with a new version.

properties.title: These are the People in the Neighborhood
properties.description: Sherri Williams (June 08) and colleagues at the Columbus Dispatch are producing a long-term project on the neighborhoods in Franklin County.  Some of the profiles have multimedia content.

properties.title: Your Government
properties.description: This site allows you to find your state and U.S. representatives by entering your <a href="http://gov.oregonlive.com/lookup/1320-SW-Broadway/Portland/">address</a> and tracks <a href="http://gov.oregonlive.com/legislators/Jason-Atkinson/">all of their votes</a> in the state legislature or congress. The site also <a href="http://gov.oregonlive.com/bill/SB998/">tracks every bill</a> through the Oregon Legislature, providing the status of the bill, vote results and links to the text of the bill and audio files of relevant committee meetings.

properties.title: Lowriders, Los Angeles and the immigration debate
properties.description: Lowriders, Los Angeles and the immigration debate

properties.title: UH's MBA program succeeds in Vietnam
properties.description: A look at the University of Hawaii's executive MBA program in Vietnam that includes a video story.

properties.title: UH professor helps boost Vietnam's clinics
properties.description: A look at an innovative program that uses principles of business franchising -- similar to McDonald's and KFC -- to deliver health care services in government clinics in Vietnam. Includes video.

properties.title: Journey of a Lifetime
properties.description: Print story and video produced on a trip to Cambodia in 2006. I worked with a local television station and we ran the television stories and print stories together and cross promoted it. Click on the links to see the video and other stories.

properties.title: A mobile health solution
properties.description: In Oakland and other cities in the West, traveling asthma clinics address a common problem: The people who suffer the most from pollution often have the least access to treatment. This video accompanies the story, <a href="http://www.hcn.org/issues/42.17/breathing-easy">"Breathing easy."</a>

properties.title: Birds shift in annual migration
properties.description: The print story on spring migration had a companion online story that linked readers to a Caspio database where they could input bird sightings around the Tampa Bay area. Sightings were tied to a Google map that plotted sightings by address or intersection. A separate photo gallery let birdwatchers upload photos of birds they had seen during the spring migration.

properties.title: "Hearts are broken" in toddler's death
properties.description: A day-long search for a missing 2-year-old demanded frequent updates online throughout the day, including still photos I shot and uploaded to TBO.com. I also did a live on-air talkback with the weekend anchor after the sheriff's press conference. Finally, I wrote a story for the next day's print edition built around a second-day lead.

properties.title: Go Down Under in Kansas
properties.description: Ralph Gage and reporters from the Lawrence Journal World explored bat caves, undergroud storage vaults and salt mines using audio, video, photo galleries and 360-degree panoramas (Ralph was a speaker at the March 08 KDMC workshop).

properties.title: Pasco County hopes for high-tech jobs
properties.description: A story about Pasco County's effort to lure high-tech job and transform the local bedroom community featured a front-page print story, a local section print story, a television package and a TBO Flash graphic detailing the county's employment base.

properties.title: Tampa  Bay area's Hispanic population is growing
properties.description: A print story based on new Census population estimates was tied to an online story that included a Flash map showing the change in Hispanic population by county for the Tampa Bay region.

properties.title: Cloquet River Flash Map
properties.description: Gustave Axelson (Jan '10) produced a package about his canoe trip on the Cloquet River with an interactive Flash map. Axelson supported colleagues to create a package on <a href="http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/volunteer/mayjun10/straight_river.html"> trout angling </a> with a video/photo slideshow, and a feature on <a href="http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/volunteer/mayjun10/trendsetters.html"> Eco Yards </a> with a Flash illustration.

properties.title: Community Capital Helps to fund Remedy Cafe
properties.description: Stephanie Ogburn (Jan '10) produced a multimedia package on Remedy Cafe, a North Oakland coffee shop that courted investment capital from friends and customers instead of banks.

properties.title: From Fellini to Lady Gaga: a new exhibit showcases the birth of Paparazzi
properties.description: Long before Gaga’s “Paparazzi”, there was Fellini’s “La Dolce Vita”

properties.title: Corn — a precious commodity on the table, in the tank
properties.description:
After participating at the KDMC’s fellowship “boot camp” the following week I put into practice and incorporated multimedia techniques I learned: video, map, chart and Storify. I linked the food aspect of this story to the importance of this commodity as a fuel alternative. 

“Corn is one of the most important commodities in the world. It is in products such as glue, makeup and alternative fuels…”

properties.title: Weepin’ Willie: Requiem for a bluesman
properties.description: Weepin’ Willie Robinson, a bluesman and one of the New England scene’s most revered figures dies in a fire while smoking his last cigarette. Robinson, 81, the son of a sharecropper, an Army veteran, and a beloved bluesman lived a complicated live. During a “memorial jam” in his honor, “a steady stream of colleagues and friends... describe Robinson as a gentle, kind and beloved charmer. At the same time, other tales paint him as the proverbial “rolling stone,” a man who left his wife to raise their eight kids alone while he set out for a music career in ...

properties.title: More older Americans start own businesses
properties.description: I shot a video featuring 65-year-old Patrick Althizer, who veered off from a career in finance to start his own business: leading shutterbugs through the stunning waterfall areas of Yosemite National Park

properties.title: Blogging from the Cannes ad fest
properties.description: I covered the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity, which is considered the Oscars of the advertising world.  I detailed the business side of advertising (such as how much money marketers spend each year to promote their goods and services) and added multimedia elements to the blog as well (such as photos and videos of winning ads and well-known attendees.)

properties.title: The Canoes Overhead: Nancy Rubins’ Epic New Sculpture at the Albright-Knox Is Whatever You Make of It
properties.description: A voluminous sculpture of about 60 tangled, aluminum boats has been turning heads skyward since construction started on June 6 at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery. Our unique take on the story, with selected photographs.

properties.title: Residents discuss redistricting issues
properties.description: A group of nearly 40 residents and city staffers held an in-depth discussion on the city’s redistricting process Monday night at the Ethel Hart Senior Center. Residents explored a range of topics, including the role of race in the process.

properties.title: Ashby's District 1 grew 123 percent
properties.description: Sacramento City Councilwoman Angelique Ashby’s district has grown 123 percent since 2000, skyrocketing from a population of 47,670 in 2000 to a population of 106,729 in 2010. But it won’t stay that way for much longer – the city intends to chop it up in this year’s redistricting process.

properties.title: Create an online redistricting map
properties.description: Sacramento residents can use the city’s online tools to carve up the eight City Council districts and present their redistricting ideas to city leaders.

properties.title: City Council aims to lessen police budget cuts
properties.description: The Sacramento Police Officers Association protests the city's proposals to lay off cops and make other budget cuts to the Sacramento Police Department.

properties.title: Video: searching for salmon off Half Moon Bay
properties.description: The salmon season has been essentially closed in California for three years, but it opened in May 2011. Fisherman Duncan MacLean is excited about the opening, but worries that there aren't enough fish in the ocean to sustain him and other fishermen. We head out for a day at sea to check out the waters.

properties.title: AIDS+30: The Battle Rages On
properties.description:
Unless you’ve been under a rock, you’ll know the 30 anniversary of the AIDS virus is this Sunday.

And if you didn’t know, this just proves the point that not enough people know the facts, nor do they understand the importance, of ending this deadly epidemic.

At shades Magazine, we mark this anniversary with a video we made to help promote awareness and increased funding to eradicate the disease and to save at least one life with the message that is our responsibility to educate ourselves, our children and those around us about HIV/AIDS.

properties.title: Hawaii Five-0 World Premiere on Waikiki Beach 2010
properties.description:
Heidi Chang takes you to the world premiere of the new Hawaii Five-0, Hawaiian style. Meet the show's cast members, Alex O'Loughlin, Scott Caan, Daniel Dae Kim, Grace Park and Taryn Manning, and executive producer Peter Lenkov, as they stroll down the red carpet on Waikiki Beach.   

Also joining them on stage: Executive producers Robert Orci and Alex Kurtzman. 

Heidi produced, wrote and narrated the video for Honolulu Municipal Television.

properties.title: Locals Work to Stop Child Sex Trafficking Problem
properties.description: Sacramento has ranked as high as second as a child prostitution hotspot in the U.S. It's up there with cities like Las Vegas, Chicago, New York City and Oakland. The subject of selling sex and children is disturbing to many people, but in the Sacramento region, many community groups have been galvanized to help combat the problem locally and globally. Web Producer Maneeza Iqbal and I created a comprehensive report to highlight the problem, anti-trafficking experts, pending legislation, and resources available. Check out the extended videos clips, maps, and charts.

properties.title: Wine From the Old World: In Buffalo, a Tradition From Italy Lives On
properties.description: A classic Buffalo story, told through images, a slide show and text. We explore Buffalo's Italian history through the story of one local family and their tradition of making wine the old-fashioned way.

properties.title: Rapper M-Bone killed in drive-by shooting
properties.description: Police believe that M-Bone, born Montae Talbert, may have been gunned down over a Twitter beef.

properties.title: Video: Kern County's economy gains as commodity prices rise
properties.description: The run-up in gold and silver prices leads to the reopening of a mine near Mojave, and higher crude prices give a boost to the county's oil fields. Crops such as cotton also are soaring in value. But some workers feel left behind.

properties.title: Coyne v. Wells on election stasis, the polls, and what leaders are doing in Toronto
properties.description: Two of Maclean's top columnists do their weekly politics segment. This one occurs mid-election campaign, so you'll find them discussing the latest polls.

properties.title: A 15,000 views video... made with my bberry
properties.description:
Here's one proof that content -or interest- surpass quality.
It was known some people pass out watching Danny Boyle's movie 127 hours.  Happens all around the US, according with media reports.
The night I went to see the movie, at the Embarcadero theaters in San Francisco, not one, but two! guys fainted.
I made this video using my cellphone, then editing in i-movie and finally posted in youtube.  After a day, the SF Weekly used it to support a blog post.  In 3 moths, the video has been watching more than 10,000 times, and it's still ...

properties.title: Filmmakers and musicians collaborate in the wild for the ‘National Parks Project’
properties.description: A series of interviews with the makers of the National Parks Project, an omnibus of short films about national parks in Canada.

properties.title: L.A. Residents Urged to Turn in Guns
properties.description: For the 3rd year, Los Angeles has hosted the Gun Buy-Back program to make communities safer.

properties.title: Retirees boost population of Lincoln, Calif., but not its commerce
properties.description: Lincoln, California grew 282% over the decade, boosted in part by a large retirement community built there. But commerce hasn't followed, and the town is out of money and forced to provide four times the services. For more, check out the story Retirees boost population of Lincoln, Calif., but not its commerce at http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-old-town-20110428,0,912702.story

properties.title: Interactive: Listen to some of the characters at the Desert Market
properties.description: The Desert Market is located in Daggett, a desert town that appears abandoned. But for locals, it's a lifeline -- for beer, energy drinks, cigarettes, and most important, the store's owner, who they call Joe. Meet some of Joe's frequent customers through this Flash project

properties.title: The musicman's birthday
properties.description: I was sent to the city's minor league baseball stadium, a farm for the San Francisco Giants where the World Series trophy was being displayed for the public. I wasn't prepared to shoot video but finding a unique character playing music to the waiting crowd, I whipped out the new iPhone and shot some video, editing in Final Cut Pro. I was nearing the end of my shift so it was a quick edit but worked fine. Wait for the end. -eric

properties.title: The Gulf spill: A year later
properties.description: This was one of our largest ongoing projects for 2010, and the updates continue. We weaved photos, video and some database work into this Flash interactive.

properties.title: Radio Legend Art Laboe on the Dedication
properties.description:
Pioneering radio personality Art Laboe was the first DJ to play Rock and Roll on the West Coast airwaves.  He put together the first compilation album which featured hits by different artists and is credited with coining the term “Oldies But Goodies.”

Over the decades, Art Laboe has remained hugely popular among generations of Latinos who call in by the dozens to dedicated and request their favorite Oldie.

properties.title: Rural Rabble Rousing
properties.description: Much of inland California is rural and poor, a sharp contrast with hip, upscale coastal life. Residents in the rural regions sometimes live with a high degree of pollution. Producer Devin Robins visited three women who became activists over concerns for their communities’ health.

properties.title: Managing Your Money Through the Ages
properties.description: Marketplace Money joins forces with The New York Times to bring you  stories about life's financial issues as they play out through the decades.  It's a a special multimedia collaboration called "Money Through the Ages."

properties.title: Faces of Freedom
properties.description: Photo editor Larry Ruehl read that more than 850 World War II veterans die each day across America, so the SouthtownStar set out to document the area men and women who served in the war while they were still with us. We photographed nearly 200 people, interviewed many of them and collected questionnaires from all of them. We published a special print section on Veterans Day and produced an online presentation that involved audio, video, a slideshow, a searchable database and an online map.

properties.title: Disgrace: St. Matthew's Church Is Falling Apart. Who Will Save It?
properties.description: The first in a pair of stories on St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo. Congregants laid St. Matthew's' cornerstone in October 1911. The church had many good years, but the last mass took place in 1993 as Buffalo's population plummeted. Now, as the church turns 100, it's literally falling to pieces. Rain blows in through broken windows. Paint flakes from the walls.

properties.title: Closing a Cold Case: Police Solve the Murder of Joseph Thomas Jr.
properties.description: The phone call that Joseph Thomas Sr. had been waiting for since August 2003 finally came this March. After more than seven years, police had finally solved his son’s murder. A short update, with video, on a story we published in January 2011 on the then-unsolved murder of Joseph Thomas Jr.

properties.title: Healthy Hillsborough: How we eat, where we eat it and how it affects our lives
properties.description: An in-depth look at some of the environmental factors that impact health in Hillsborough County, Florida, such as the number of fast-food restaurants, grocery stores and public parks.

properties.title: "Good of Bad" YouTube Changing the world.
properties.description: As long as YouTube, Social Media and word of mouth exist, web videos are without a doubt changing the way the world communicates, from news to music, to how-to videos, to stories of triumph and defeat. Yet not all is good show recent reports and studies. (@espiblog Multimedia exercise KDMC UC Berkeley)

properties.title: Lampedusa, gateway to Europe
properties.description: Thousands of people from Tunisia are fleeing from their country. They don't believe that the revolution will bring soon a better future. And they risk their life sailing towards Italy, to enter Europe for a better life. Hundreds of people everyday land in Lampedusa, a tiny island, south of Sicily. There's already a humanitarian crisis but, in spite of the fearmongering that some members of the Berlusconi government spread, ordinary people of Lampedusa react very well to the so-called "invasion". As this webdocumentary tries to demonstrate.

properties.title: Misuse of Welfare is Minimal, Data Show
properties.description: Republican state lawmakers in Minnesota have proposed new restrictions to prevent poor people from spending welfare money on alcohol, tobacco and lottery tickets. However, available data suggests misuse of welfare money is minimal. Instead, people who receive welfare said the legislation would make it impossible to use the money for basic needs, like paying rent and doing laundry.

properties.title: American Dream Alive in Maricopa
properties.description: A story mapping home based businesses in the city of Maricopa.

properties.title: Census: Maricopa population tops 43,000
properties.description: Story on the newly released census data for the city of Maricopa.

properties.title: Inside Al Jazeera
properties.description: For weeks now the qatari tv has been telling the world about the protests in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya. They have also been accused, in a way, to instigate them. But its journalists, starting from a twenty-something whiz-kid who knows everything about Facebook and Twitter, rebut: "We're simply the best at covering them"

properties.title: Explore how the region has changed since 2000
properties.description: MAPublisher maps showing population, percent minority, and under 18 population by tract in King, Snohomish, Pierce, and Kitsap counties in Washington state.

properties.title: Audio librarian Jeff Rice captures the sounds of the West
properties.description: An audio slideshow in which Jeff Rice discusses how he collects sound and plays some of the sounds from the Western Soundscape Archive.

properties.title: Chicago's Black comic book movement
properties.description: Chicago native and artist Turtel Onli created an annual convention that gives graphic novelists and comic book artists a venue to showcase their work and to expose comic book fans to the Black Age in the comic book genre.

properties.title: North Jersey black families leaving for lure of new South
properties.description: A story about the dwindling black population in North Jersey. The graphic shows population by town, from 1990, 2000 and 2010 census, and by census tract for 2010, as a percent of the total population.

properties.title: The Peters Poll with LaMonica Peters
properties.description: This is the Facebook Page I created shortly before the Web 2.0 workshop but I enhanced it after learning more about using Facebook for journalistic purposes. I hope to create a larger fan base, & add more video.

properties.title: Are Mosquitos Putting Cal Students at Risk?
properties.description: This is my 1st attempt at using Final Cut Pro to edit video. Don't judge me. LOL

properties.title: King Tide Hints At Shoreline's Future
properties.description: The powerful pull of sun and moon alignment, along with a powerful storm, created high waves lapping at the land of the San Francisco Bay Area.

properties.title: Weyerhaeuser earnings
properties.description: A Tableau data visualization of the Weyerhaeuser Q4 2010 earnings released on Feb. 4, 2010. Part of a series of earnings data visualizations, which includes Starbucks, Boeing, Paccar, Microsoft, and other area businesses.

properties.title: How an old problem became a new crisis
properties.description: A Flash graphic describing the problems with the aging Howard Hanson Dam, the possible effects of its failure, and a temporary solution being implemented.

properties.title: North Jersey town-by-town data from the 2010 Census
properties.description: Town by town census data for the North Jersey coverage area of The Record

properties.title: Wilderness Photographer
properties.description: This video accompanies the piece My walkabout with Michael, in which New Mexican writer Pat Toomay shadows Guggenheim award-winning photographer Michael Berman through the Gila wilderness. This multimedia features an interview with Berman where he reads a poem about his process of going into the wild and finding images, and discusses why he became a photographer and his views on the relationship of humans to nature.

properties.title: Getting to work from North Jersey
properties.description: Charts comparing commute time and departure time for the U.S., N.J. and Bergen and Passaic counties in New Jersey.

properties.title: Average gas price hits $3 in Bergen-Passaic, again
properties.description: Graphic on the price of gas over a two and a half year period, from when gas was at $4 a gallon to a low of $1.25 a gallon and back up to $3 a gallon.

properties.title: December is worst month for driving in N.J., analysis shows
properties.description: Two Protovis charts to accompany a story about accidents on North Jersey roads in December.

properties.title: Whistler's new digs
properties.description: An interactive guide to the Olympic venues at Whistler.

properties.title: A quick guide to the world of beer
properties.description: Overwhelmed by the vast selection of beers at the local market? Are you stumped when the brewmaster asks if you prefer ales or lagers? If the answer is yes, then this guide to the world of beer is for you.

properties.title: Which industry has the most workers injury claims?
properties.description: The restaurant and construction industries have the highest number of workers' compensation claims filed with the state Department of Labor & Industries. Employers with frequent injury claims are assessed higher rates.

properties.title: Bank failures hit new record
properties.description: A record 157 banks nationwide failed in 2010 as regulators seized more ailing banks unable to raise capital or find a merger partner. Eleven of those banks were in Washington state.

properties.title: Timeswatch
properties.description: A monthly look at the indicators shaping the Puget Sound area's economy.

properties.title: EngageWisconsin
properties.description: EngageWisconsin is an online community engagement portal created by Wisconsin Public Television. Spearheaded by a 2010 KDMC Fellow, the site is focused on: 1) producing multimedia storytelling projects, promoting WPT and PBS documentaries & programming, 2) developing a platform through which WI residents can blog on program-related subjects, and 3) encourage viewer-created content. The site explores how to take viewers behind-the-scenes while also providing an interactive platform through which WI residents can share their stories, learn from one another, and discuss local issues. Ultimately, we see it as a place where Wisconsin residents and their diverse voices connect.

properties.title: Another way of remembering
properties.description: A blog post describing the creation of The Poppy File, a multimedia project launched by OpenFile for Remembrance Day 2010. During World War II, more than 3,200 people from Toronto died in service. We mapped the addresses of their next of kin and displayed them with the name, rank and place of death of the fallen servicemen.

properties.title: Video Goes Uptown
properties.description:
This is a story about the project that launched Uptown Media Arts.  
It was written by Berkeley J-School graduate Priyanka Sharma-Sindhar.

properties.title: Ghent blaze that burned two buildings called arson
properties.description: Late night reporting and video production by Patrick Wilson and Shayna Meliker.

properties.title: Portsmouth, Va., burn victim has Saints on his side
properties.description: Story about a surprise gift for a burn victim includes photo/audio slideshow.

properties.title: The Desert Lockout: Miners Continue Street Actions, as Negotiations Restart (Slideshow)
properties.description: BORON, CALIF.—It’s 6:15 a.m. and cars and trucks are coming down the long stretch of desert road to the main gate at the Rio Tinto/Borax facility. Soon, scores of vans and buses filled with replacement workers—what more than 500 locked-out workers call “scabs”—will be shuttled in and out of the gates. Union workers of Rio Tinto line the road, with bullhorns, shining lights at the passengers, jeering and hurling insults.

properties.title: Hardly Strictly Business: Cal Alum Warren Hellman Plays to His Own Tune in Investing, Philanthropy
properties.description: A profile of private equity financier, San Francisco power broker, and Cal graduate Warren Hellman

properties.title: FIEBRE DEL POTOMAC
properties.description: News blog

properties.title: Online Tamil Songs
properties.description: Hearing Tamil songs online will never be difficult any more; A2Z Tamil Songs dot com offers all Tamil mp3 songs in one site from 1960s to till date. We can browse songs by music director, Cinema director vocalist, and also a2z by film name as the name of the website suggests.

properties.title: Federal Money Accounts for a Quarter of Florida's Economy
properties.description: Examination of 2009 federal spending in Florida and Tampa Bay area shows who's likely to feel the pinch the most when and if newly elected members of Congress keep their pledges to rein in the budget deficit. With interactive map showing per-capita spending by Florida county, Flash-based graphics showing spending over time and breakdown by category, and searchable database of spending at all levels statewide.

properties.title: Historias de supervivencia
properties.description: Bilingual and Multimedia Project on Domestic Violence in the Latino Community. I was the adviser of this student project multimedia production.

properties.title: Berkeley's Coffee Economy
properties.description:
A profile of one popular Berkeley cafe and how the US recession has affected its business and the consumption habits of coffee drinkers.

Produced at Knight Digital Media Center in Berkeley with former NPR reporter, John McChesney. Shot and edited in one morning and afternoon in April 2009.

properties.title: Smokin'
properties.description:
A character study of anti-anti-smoking activist, Lynda Farley.

The short incorporates the still photography of Mark Katzman, video footage from his partner, Scott Ferguson, both of the St. Louis-based commercial studio, FKPhoto.

Chip recorded the interview with Farley during the photo shoot at various sites in St. Louis in September 2009.

properties.title: Amsterdam's Lucrative Cannabis Culture: Can it Work in California
properties.description:
The measure that would legalize the sale and recreational use of marijuana in California is sparking heated debate. 
	In the Netherlands, marijuana is “tolerated.” Pot use and sales are legal-- to a certain degree. Pot-selling coffeeshops generate billions of dollars.  Could it work in California?
	Multimedia journalists Suzanne Phan and Ryan Yamamoto take a closer look at Amsterdam’s cannabis culture and the economic impact of taxing marijuana. And, they explain why Amsterdam is closely watching Prop 19.

properties.title: Canon DM-100 Directional Stereo Microphone for Camcorders
properties.description: This is a well-researched Review of the Canon DM-100 Directional Stereo Microphone for Camcorders

properties.title: After the Chino Prison Riot
properties.description: Public Insight Journalism crowdsourcing and traditional reporting methods combine to tell the story of the Chino prison riot of August 2009. The web presentation includes dozens of letters written by inmates of a California prison describing conditions before, during and after the riot. Some of the men were held outdoors in metal cages with inadequate clothing and shelter for days after the riot. The story came to KPCC via sources responding to general questions to the public about prison life. One of our sources won the SPJ Sunshine Award for efforts to make government more open.

properties.title: It's a Wrap: The "Grill 'Em All" Food Truck Makeover
properties.description:
At the Wrap One shop in Anaheim, a small team transforms blank-slate "taco trucks" into billboards on wheels.

Watch the metamorphosis of the "Grill 'Em All" truck.

***

A Concepts Completos production in association with the documentary: Masa Revolution

***

(Freelance photography and editing by Corey Takahashi / Music courtesy of Shadows Fall)

properties.title: US visa laws lightened for Cuban artists
properties.description:
On his first visit to Latin America President Obama said he'd like to start a path of normalizing relations with Cuba. While visiting Mexico City, Mr. Obama also implied that the frozen relationship would not thaw unless Cuba relaxed pressure on political dissidents.

At the same time, Mr. Obama has allowed more Cuban artists--even those openly critical of U-S policy--to come to the United States.

This story is pegged to the visits of three well-known artists and musicians, all of whom have differing opinions on the delicate dance Washington & Havana are engaged in.

properties.title: Mexico: Human Rights & Press Freedom
properties.description:
This is a profile of one courageous journalist's battle to expose police corruption, manipulation of both the media and the lives of those who speak out against abuses of power by government and an explanation of how this landmark case came to the world's attention. 

The fact the journalist is a woman in a machista society complicates an already horrendous breach of human rights, one which is being examined by lawyers internationally.

properties.title: Reworking the US-Mexico Water Treaty
properties.description:
The Colorado River has been nearly tapped dry as a consequence of exploding populations in the southwest border region combined with the voracious appetite of American agribusiness. 

Mexico and the U-S are now negotiating a decades-old water sharing treaty. If successful, the revamped treaty could provide a model for conserving a vital but finite resource.

properties.title: Where the lottery takes the biggest bite
properties.description: Flash map showing analysis of lottery ticket sales and Bright Futures scholarship awards by ZIP code in Hillsborough County, Fla.

properties.title: Democrats and Republicans Hit Voter Rallies
properties.description: Democrats and Republicans hit voter rallies in Nueces County. We were there to talk to locals about what happened and to get photos of their appearance.

properties.title: AHS Jazz Band Sent to Lincoln Center
properties.description: This video brings viewers into a practice session of this award-winning jazz band on the eve of a trip to Lincoln Center. The video zooms in for close ups on two of the most stellar performers as they regal listeners with solos.

properties.title: Video: Take the Walking School Bus on Wednesday For Health, Environment
properties.description: Video follows the "Walking School Bus" one morning as the bus picks up kids along its route and makes its way to Marin School in Albany. Interviews with the organizer, some kids and the school principal along the way.

properties.title: Hawaii Ukulele Festival (Audio story and video performane)
properties.description: Heidi Chang takes you to the 40th annual Ukulele Festival in Hawaii. The instrument has seen a resurgence lately around the globe, thanks in part to musician Jake Shimabukuro. Listen to the audio story Heidi produced for Public Radio International's The World. You can also watch a slideshow of the festival and video Heidi produced of Jake Shimabukuro performing "While My Guitar Gently Weeps."

properties.title: Columbia Stink Map
properties.description: Crowd sourcing of where people in Columbia, South Carolina smelled something foul on Tuesday, Oct. 26. Reporters tracked down the source of the odor to a farm south of the city, where the owner (a former city councilman) had spread fertilizer.

properties.title: Detroit crime victims, victimized again
properties.description:
Eighty-nine year old Irene Phimister was beaten to an inch of her life over six dollars and a handful of jewelry so a few guys could feed their heroin habit. Irene is owed $1,200 but has yet to see it. Hundreds of crime victims like her in Metro Detroit are still waiting on millions in restitution money to be mailed to them. The process to pay has been a long, slow and often times non-existent. The prosecutors and clerks office blame each other while the money just sits in a bank and victims sit and wait.
ERIC SEALS/Detroit ...

properties.title: Who wins or loses from mass immigration?
properties.description: Part 3 of OC Register immigration series examines impact of immigration on wages. Scroll down left side of story to link to interactive charts showing shift in wages by education and occupation from 1970 to 2008.

properties.title: California's addiction to immigrant labor
properties.description:
California is addicted to immigrant labor.
Over the past four decades, the state has come to depend on immigrant brains and brawn to an extent unmatched by any other state and almost any developed country.

properties.title: Animal Hoarding in Fort Wayne
properties.description: May 2009 fellow Ron Shawgo shares this video on the increasingly serious problem of animal hoarding.

properties.title: The Art of the Foul Ball
properties.description: May 2008 fellow Eric Seals records the stories of those lucky enough to grab a major league baseball souvenir. More multimedia coverage of that same day at the ballpark can be found here.

properties.title: Video revisists 40-year-old case of slain journalist
properties.description: January 2008 fellow Robert Lopez produced this video on deadline last week about former L.A. Times columnist Ruben Salazar's death. Questions and controversy still cloud the 40-year-old case.

properties.title: Brown Pelican Release
properties.description: Vanessa Deggins reports on The Louisiana Dept of Wildlife and Fisheries and their first in-state release of Brown Pelicans impacted by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

properties.title: First Lake Charles Black Rodeo
properties.description: Vanessa Deggins reports on Lake Charles's first Real Cowboy Association Rodeo. The association was started years ago in Longview, TX for black cowboys, but has since integrated and everyone competes.

properties.title: Crime on Cruise Ships
properties.description: Jaclyn Giovis presents video and data to help cruise passengers avoid crime.

properties.title: Five Years Later: Hurricane Katrina
properties.description: January 20008 fellow Julia Schmalz contributed work to producing a multimedia site which recalls the devastation associated with Hurricane Katrina.

properties.title: Whitening The Resume
properties.description: With blacks being re-employed during the recovery at a slower pace than whites, should black candidates consider removing ethnic references from their resumes?

properties.title: New Site Combines Social Networking and Digital Media
properties.description: News Entrepreneurs Boot Camp fellow Ingrid Sturgis helped produce fully-connected.com, which "connects people from Atlanta to Accra through engaging journalism and social networking."

properties.title: OC Register Immigrant Labor Series
properties.description: April 2008 fellow Ron Campbell has posted Part 2 of OC Register's series on immigrants and the California economy. This part examines the breakdown of immigration law enforcement. Also see interactive maps (click the 'maps' tab).

properties.title: Video Promotes UC's PRIME Medical Program
properties.description: July 2008 fellow Alec Rosenberg shares this video about UC's PRIME (Program in Medical Education). PRIME trains doctors to serve where they are needed most in California.

properties.title: Meera's articles
properties.description: Links to Meera's articles can be found here.

properties.title: Sidney Barnes on Stone Cold Feeling
properties.description: A favorite record of mine, a B-Side from 1971, was written in Chicago, featured a Chicago artist and players, was recorded in Chicago, and was released on a Chicago label (Mercury). I had the opportunity to talk to the man who wrote it, Sidney Barnes, about it; and I flashed-back vicariously through him (he hadn't heard the track in thirty years).

properties.title: Birds shift in annual migration
properties.description: The print story on spring migration had a companion online story that linked readers to a Caspio database where they could input bird sightings around the Tampa Bay area. Sightings were tied to a Google map that plotted sightings by address or intersection. A separate photo gallery let birdwatchers upload photos of birds they had seen during the spring migration.
